noun.description: In poetry, the repetition of the sound of a vowel or diphthong in nonrhyming stressed syllables near enough to each other for the echo to be discernible (e.g., penitence, reticence)
examples: the use of assonance throughout the poem creates the sound of despair
alliterative assonances such as “fail” and “fall” are very common in Old English poetry

origin: Early 18th century: from French, from Latin assonare respond to, from ad- to + sonare (from sonus sound).
